newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai shoppers sampling IMF economic medicine.
newsitem.headline: Thai shoppers sampling IMF economic medicine.

text.p: Thais were waking up to a sense of new economic reality as the first austerity measure under a new International Monetary Fund-sposored plan saw prices jump due to a value added tax increase over the weekend.
VAT rose to 10 percent from seven percent, sending prices of most goods, other than exempted fresh foods, higher from Saturday.
The increase had sparked a surge in consumer spending last week with some shops reporting 20 percent rise in sales over the week before as shoppers stocked up ahead of the tax increase.
Business in malls and shops had returned to normal over the weekend, managers and shop workers said.
"It's not busy now. I think a lot of people are staying at home more because the economy is not good," said an assistant at an empty clothing outlet in an upmarket mall in Bangkok.
After years of heady growth and conspicious consumption by many affluent Thais, local media have begun listing money saving ideas as household budgets tighten to meet the new reality.
"I don't normally come to this mall but the prices are a bit cheaper here and I think people are looking more for that now," said one young woman.

The increased VAT levy should bring an additional 66 billon baht into government coffers, and along with a 57 billion baht ($1.8 billion) budget cut, is among the first of austerity measures expected to be adopted to secure about $16 billion in IMF organised funding to help prop up the creaking economy.
Thailand is facing its severest economic crisis for decades.

Slowing economic growth last year, a slump in exports, investment in unproductive sectors and recent currency instability have eroded investor confidence in an economy which had become heavily reliant of foreign investment.
